page.title: 09SOCIAL CONCERNS
page.content: In a limestone area water supply is an issue of significance. The town of Much Wenlock derived its water from a number of wells scattered round the town & which remain today in walls of houses & gardens. Their significance is exemplified in that they are named after saints eg. St. Owens well. The town is served by a stream,Farley brook, which rises on the dip slope of Wenlock Edge,flows E. into the town & turns to flow N. into R. Severn creating the valley of Farley dingle. Homer obtained water from wells & boreholes. Until the late 1960's Much Wenlock had its own water supply from a tank high on the scarp behind the hospital. With the expansion of Homer the area was connected to the Severn- Trent main. Many isolated dwellings still obtain water from boreholes.
